He recalled how a hockey coach was on the lookout for a goalkeeper and his eyes fell upon Mohith. â€œI was playing volleyball and hockey, one session of volleyball and then hockey,â€ Mohith told Scroll. â€œAnd after that I basically decided to go on with hockey because I didnâ€™t add more height to continue volleyball.â€From then on, it was all about progressing through the different age levels and working towards the ultimate goal of representing his country on the international stage. â€œI wasnâ€™t going to college because I could practice more. And I still think (I have to) work a lot in order to get into the senior team and to win the World Cup,â€ he said.The Indian menâ€™s junior team recently won the Menâ€™s Junior Hockey Asia Cup earlier this month, beating Pakistan 2-1 and Mohith was given the accolade of the Goalkeeper of the Tournament. Rightly awarded to the 21-year old, as Mohith and the Indian defence conceded only four goals in six matches in the Asia Cup. Speaking to Scroll after his title-winning performance in the tournament, Mohith credited his exploits during the matches in Oman to his â€˜trial by fireâ€™ about seven months earlier at his international tournament debut - the 2022 Sultan of Johor Cup.India were crowned Junior Asia Cup winners | AHFMohith began his international career in memorable fashion â€“ keeping calm during a penalty shootout against Australia in the Johor Cup final. The result â€“ Mohith denied Joshua Brooks the chance to level and India lifted the title for the first time since 2014. Watching the highlights of the final in Malaysia, one would not assume that it was Mohithâ€™s rookie international tournament. On the surface, the 21-year-old was unflappable, but inside, he was incredibly tense and stressed. Conceding that he didnâ€™t have a lot of experience upon entering the tournament (19 goals conceded in 6 matches), Mohith was honest about the challenges he faced in the Sultan of Johor Cup. â€œPlaying as a rookie in the team is hard. As goalkeeper, there was a lot of pressure and stress on me,â€ he added.â€œThe pressure and stress is very good and will make you play very well in the game if you have the experience.â€Meet Uttam Singh, the young forward who led India as they reclaimed the Sultan of Johor CupGranted, the calibre of teams faced in the Sultan of Johor Cup, according to Mohith, was significantly higher than who they competed against in the Asia Cup (India conceded one goal each to Japan and Korea and two to Pakistan). But Mohith pointed to the experience gained in playing against teams like Australia and Great Britain in Malaysia as part of his and the teamâ€™s success in winning the Asia Cup.As a goalkeeper, there are moments in a game when you are all alone in your half and watching as your attack runs riot in the scoreline. Mohith was in a similar position throughout the group stage of the Asia Cup with score lines like 18-0 against Chinese Taipei and 17-0 against Thailand. â€œThe problem is, if the match is one-sided, like the score is about 10-0, there is no high probability the ball wonâ€™t come to our team. So the main thing is to be ready â€“ communicating with the team members, being involved in the game and doing some exercises,â€ he explained.â€œIf the ball doesnâ€™t come, also moving around in the team and interacting with the players makes us be in the game for a longer period. When you are playing against a good team but you are up by 3-4 goals, then you should be really alert.â€Mohith indicated that it was imperative for a goalkeeper to maintain their focus irrespective of the scoreline. With conviction and the air of a seasoned player, he said, â€œItâ€™s a duality situation for a goalkeeper â€“ we should not take any pressure. Even if we are leading, we should be active. Even though we are losing, we should be active and we should not lose confidence.â€That was on display in the final. When India started well and had a two-goal lead, there was no time to relax because Pakistan came roaring back. Mohith, though, was alert. In the second quarter, he put out his left leg for a world-class reflex save to make sure India led 2-0 going into the half time. In the third and quarters, when an increasingly nervous Indian defence brought pressure up on themselves, Mohith was working overtime. There was a phase of play where he and the defence had to pull off saves after saves and blocks after blocks to keep the lead.Mohith HS in action during the Junior Men's Asia Cup in Oman on June 1, 2023 | Credit: Hockey IndiaSreejeshâ€™s insightsA lot of the advice and knowledge that Mohith and the other goalkeepers in the junior menâ€™s team have gotten (including strategies to employ during penalty shootouts) is courtesy their senior counterparts in PR Sreejesh and Krishan Pathak among others. And now he (Mohith) has gained a lot of confidence and he can contest with the seniors at any moment.â€Mohith himself was very thankful for the presence of seniors like Sreejesh and Pathak who were able to spend some time with the junior goalkeepers during their training in Bengaluru. â€œJust little tips and tricks from him so that you can boost your performance,â€ said Mohith, as he recollected the session with the menâ€™s senior team. â€œHe came to our training one day for the goalkeepers and it was good because our basics was only corrected by Sree bhai. Speaking about Mohithâ€™s performance at the Asia Cup, Kumar added, â€œOf course, he can challenge anybody in the seniors at the moment. He was the best goalkeeper of the tournament.
